concern:
So I have a triple dorm (the third roommate never showed up), and my roommate is constantly out of the dorm past 10 am. I on the contrary enjoy staying inside. I do all of my studying in my dorm room as I don't feel comfortable working in front of people in the lounge or the library. I do go out for my lectures/labs, to eat, and for an hour or two to practice in a music room each day. If the weather is okay I will also go out on a hiking trail for a few hours. 

I do go home for the weekends so my roommate gets to have the dorm for herself during the weekends, but I see no sense in studying outside of my dorm room. I am currently working on getting an internship, but before I get a part-time position, I will likely continue being a homebody. Is this weird or do others here also prefer to sit in their dorm rooms? I am a STEM major, so I do have to study more than my business major roommate.

dialogue_total.statement: Hi there, thanks for reaching out. Im here to listen and help in any way I can. Whats been on your mind lately?

I've been feeling concerned about my preference for spending most of my time in my dorm room for studying and relaxing. I'm wondering if this is common for others, especially as a STEM major with a heavier workload.

It sounds like you're feeling a bit uneasy about your preference for staying in your dorm room. It's not uncommon for students, especially those with demanding majors like STEM, to spend a lot of time studying and relaxing in their own space. Have you noticed any negative impacts from this routine, or is it more of a general concern?

I haven't noticed any significant negative impacts from my routine, as it helps me focus on my STEM studies effectively. It's mostly a general concern about whether this preference is common among others with similar workloads.

It's great that you've found a routine that helps you focus on your studies. While it's normal to have concerns about your habits, it sounds like you're doing what works best for you. If you're curious about how others handle their workloads, have you considered reaching out to classmates or joining a study group to compare notes?

I've considered reaching out to classmates or joining a study group, but I prefer sticking to my current routine in my dorm for better focus on my STEM workload. I'm not sure it would be helpful for me right now, as I value the privacy it provides.

It seems like you have a good understanding of your needs and preferences when it comes to studying and managing your STEM workload. While it's natural to be curious about others' routines, it's essential to recognize that everyone has their unique ways of handling their studies. If your current routine works well for you, it's perfectly fine to stick with it. However, if you ever feel the need for a change or want to explore different study methods, remember that you can always reach out to classmates or join a study group in the future. Ultimately, it's about finding what works best for you and your academic success.

I appreciate your reassurance about my study routine, as it really helps me manage my STEM workload effectively. I'm still curious if other students with heavy workloads also prefer the privacy of their own space for focused studying.

It's understandable that you're curious about how other students manage their workloads, especially those with demanding majors like yours. While everyone has their unique preferences, it's not uncommon for students to seek solitude and quiet spaces to concentrate better on their studies. However, it's also essential to remember that people may choose various methods to balance their academic responsibilities and personal lives.

 That makes sense. I guess I'm just trying to gauge if my preference for spending most of my time in my dorm room is typical among my peers. Sometimes I worry that I might be missing out on social experiences, but at the same time, I feel more productive when I can focus on my STEM studies without distractions.

 It's completely normal to have these thoughts and concerns, and it's great that you're reflecting on your preferences and priorities. Finding a balance between academic responsibilities and social experiences can be challenging, but it's important to listen to your needs and do what feels right for you. Remember that everyone has different ways of managing their time, and there's no one-size-fits-all approach. If you feel that your current routine allows you to be productive and focused, it's perfectly fine to continue with it.

I understand that balancing studies and social life varies for everyone, and I'm glad to hear my routine might be common for STEM students. Still, I sometimes wonder if trying a mix of solo and group study could help me feel less isolated without disrupting my focus.

It's great that you're considering different approaches to find the balance that works best for you. Exploring various study methods can help you discover what makes you feel most comfortable and productive. Combining solo and group study might offer the benefits of both focused work and social interaction. Perhaps you could try joining a study group once or twice a week and see how it affects your concentration and sense of connection with your peers. Remember, it's all about finding the right balance that supports your academic success and personal well-being.

I appreciate the suggestion to try a study group occasionally, as it could help me test balancing focused work with some social interaction. However, I still value the privacy of my dorm for most studying to maintain my productivity in STEM subjects without distractions.

It's commendable that you're open to exploring different study methods while acknowledging the importance of your current routine. Finding the right balance can be a process of trial and error, so remember to be patient with yourself and listen to your needs. Perhaps you could start by setting specific days or times for group study while maintaining your private study space during other times. This way, you can gradually find the balance that allows you to be productive and feel connected with your peers without overwhelming yourself.

I appreciate the idea of scheduling specific times for group study, as it might help me experiment with social interaction without losing my routine. Still, I plan to prioritize my dorm for most studying to keep my STEM focus sharp and avoid distractions.

It's great to see that you're open to trying new approaches while also recognizing the importance of your current routine. Balancing productivity and social connection is a personal journey, and it's important to listen to your needs along the way. Remember to be patient with yourself as you explore different study methods, and keep in mind that it's okay to adjust your plans as you discover what works best for you. Good luck, and feel free to reach out again if you have any further questions or concerns.
Thank you for your guidance I'll continue prioritizing my dorm for studying to maintain focus on my STEM work, while occasionally trying group sessions as suggested. Take care.
